INFORM DETROIT

MARIHUANA PROPOSALS ON THE NOVEMBER 2017 BALLOT

There is a 2008 state law that legalizes the use of medical marihuana. From 2008 to 2015, over 280 marihuana dispensaries opened in Detroit, without regulation from the city. Responding to pressure from local groups, Detroit passed an ordinance in 2015 requiring dispensaries to apply for licenses from the City and imposing restrictions on location and hours of operation. This 2015 local ordinance is the “current city code” described in Kim’s presentation.

A 2016 state law that legalizes dispensaries, growers, processers, secure transporters, and laboratories for medical marihuana will go into effect in 2018. Cities may opt into the new Michigan law if they wish to legalize the five new uses. Operators of the five new uses would have to apply to the state for a license, and cities may charge up to $5000 per license application.

Proposals A and B are intended to opt into and align with the new state law, and address what their proponents believe to be overly stringent restrictions on marihuana uses established by the Detroit ordinance.

Proposal A would amend city code to additionally license and regulate growing facilities, processers, secure transporters and laboratories, as well as to loosen the city regulations on dispensaries. Proposal B would amend the zoning code to regulate where the five new uses can operate, and whether public hearings are required.

Considerations: Proponents of legalizing these additional uses are interested in the potential for tax and fee revenues from a new industry. Opponents fear marihuana legalization in a population already struggling with substance abuse. There is an outstanding question whether it is legal to amend the zoning ordinance by ballot referendum. In the past, Michigan’s Supreme Court has ruled that zoning ordinances cannot be amended by initiative petition. At the moment, a Wayne County circuit judge has ruled that Proposal B will remain on the November ballot.

Two Ballot Proposals compared to Current City Ordinance

Proposal A - Amends Licensing Ordinance

  • How businesses are operated

Proposal B - Amends Zoning Ordinance

  • Where businesses operate

PROP A

LICENSING

Current Code

  • Dispensaries

Proposal A

  • Dispensaries
  • Growing facilities
  • Processor
  • Transporters
  • Laboratories

HOURS OF OPERATIONS

Current Code

  • Dispensaries operate 10AM - 8PM

Proposal A

  • Dipensaries operate 9AM - 9PM
  • Other uses are not restricted

DISTANCE RESTRICTIONS

Current Code

Dispensaries not allowed within 1000 ft of:

  • Schools
  • Parks
  • Libraries
  • Childcare centers
  • Arcades
  • Liquor stores
  • Youth Activity Centers
  • Public Housing Churches
  • Other dispensaries

Proposal A

All 5 uses not allowed within 1000 ft of:

  • Schools & Libraries

Dispensaries not allowed within 500 ft of:

  • Churches & Other dispensaries

No distance restrictions for:

  • Parks, Child Care Centers, Youth Activity Centers
  • Liquor stores, Arcades, Public Housing

SIGNAGE

Current Code

  • Prohibits execessive LED lighting
  • Requires signs to be removed within 30 days of dispensary closing
  • Language not addressed due to 1st amendment concerns

Proposal A

  • Prohibits the use of the word "marihuana"
  • Prohibits images of marijuana leaves or green crosses on signs
  • Does not address lighting or removal

PROP B

ZONING DISTRICTS

Current Code

Allows dispensaries in:

  • M1 - Limited Industrial District
  • M2 - Restricted Industrial District
  • M3 - General Industrial District
  • M4 - Intensive Industrial District
  • B2 - Local Business and Residential District
  • B4 - General Business District

Proposal A

Allows all 5 uses in:

  • M1 - Limited Industrial District
  • M2 - Restricted Industrial District
  • M3 - General Industrial District
  • M4 - Intensive Industrial District
  • M5 - Special Industrial District

Allows dispensaries, processors, facilities in:

  • B1 - Restricted Business District
  • B2 - Local Business and Residential District
  • B3 - Shopping District
  • B4 - General Business District

PUBLIC INPUT

Current Code

  • Requires dispensary applicants to have public hearing before approval
  • Appeals of approval decisionsma

Proposal A

  • Allow all 5 uses to be approved without a public hearing
  • Does not allow appeals to Board of Zoning Appeals

NUISANCES

Current Code

  • Prohibits loitering outside dispensaries
  • Prohibits consumption of marihuana on the premises
  • Requires dispensary to limit odors
  • Can be shut down for not following law

Proposal A

  • Does not address nuisances or enforcement
